name: Mining truck; Manufacture; For surface mine, at plant; Gross machine operating weight  623,690 kg
description:
This process is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  To access the library and the original dataset:
1) Navigate to the NETL LCA home page (http://www.netl.doe.gov/lca)
2) Then navigate to the “Unit Process Library” 
3) From the library, the unit process of interest can be found either through the "Complete Listing of the Unit Process Library link" or through the link to the "Unit Process Database" spreadsheet
4) For each process, a Data Sheet (DS) and Data File (DF) are available

BRIEF DESCRIPTION
This unit process is based on manufacturer specifications for a Caterpillar model 797B, 623,690 kg, mining truck, to carry coal at a Powder River Basin surface mine for subbituminous coal. It quantifies the amount of steel and rubber needed for construction.		

GOAL AND SCOPE
The scope of this unit process encompasses the materials and weights of materials necessary to construct a single 623,690 kg mining truck, to be used for the transportation of coal at a surface mine located in the Powder River Basin region of the United States, during raw material acquisition. The process is based on the reference flow of 1 piece of mining truck, 623,690 kg empty truck weight, as described below, and as shown in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section below). The mining truck is assumed to be constructed of steel plate, and styrene-butadiene-rubber for the tires; therefore steel plate is assumed to be the only material required for the remainder of the truck construction. Other materials are assumed to be negligible.

This process is used during LC (Life Cycle) Stage #1 to assist in the preparation of subbituminous coal extraction process by transporting the coal within the boundaries of the surface mine. It is combined with other surface mine equipment construction unit processes in an individual assembly surface unit process for Powder River Basin sub-bituminous coal, Coal mine equipment assembly; Production mix; Surface coal mine, Powder river basin, U.S. This assembly unit process quantifies the fraction of each piece of equipment needed under LC Stage #1 to produce 1 kg of coal ready for transport (LC Stage #2) to the energy conversion facility.

BOUNDARY AND DESCRIPTION
Construction of the mining truck is based on manufacturer specifications for a Caterpillar model 797B, 623,690 kg mining truck. The mining truck is used to transport extracted coal to the crushing facility in preparation for transport. All use of the mining truck occurs within the confines of the mine.

A visual representation of the boundary of this unit process is available in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section below). Emissions related to the physical assembly of the mining truck (e.g., that are emitted while putting together the components of a mining truck, including transport of those components) are not considered in this study. Upstream emissions from the production of raw materials used for the construction of the mining truck (e.g., steel plate) are calculated outside the boundary of this unit process, based on proprietary profiles available within the GaBi model. As discussed above and shown in the associated documentation (referenced below), the mining truck constructed in this unit process is incorporated into the Powder River Basin surface mine assembly processes for LC Stage #1 for sub-bituminous coal.

The total weight of a mining truck was readily available but reliable data for the material breakdown of mining truck subcomponents aside from the tires were not. Therefore, the mining truck was assumed to be composed solely of carbon steel and rubber.

Relevant properties and assumptions used to calculate the amount of steel plate contained in a single mining truck are discussed in the associated documentation (referenced below). Total weight for one mining truck is estimated to be approximately 623,690 kg (1,375,000 lbs) (Caterpillar 2003). Based on the assumption that the truck is constructed entirely out of carbon steel with the exception of the tires which are made out of styrene-butadiene-rubber, 31,815 kg are assigned to the tires with the remainder attributed to carbon steel. Additional details regarding input and output flows, including calculation methods, are contained in the associated documentation (referenced below).

This process contains one or more surrogate product flows as replacements for proprietary product flows used in the NETL Unit Process Library.  All surrogate flow were taken from the U.S. Life Cycle Inventory Database; a list of surrogate flows used in this process is provided below:
1) Acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene copolymer, resin, at plant

CITATION AND ASSOCIATED DOCUMENTATION
This document should be cited as: 
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2015. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data – Unit Process: Mining truck; Manufacture; For surface mine, at plant; Gross machine operating weight  623,690 kg. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last Updated: September 2015 (Version  01). Retrieved on [DATE] from [URL for this dataset].

This dataset is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  The Library offers additional information concerning this dataset in the form of a Detailed Spreadsheet  Documentation (DS) file and a Process Documentation File (DF).  The DS file  is an Excel file that contains all of the parameters, inputs, and outputs for a given system as well as background data, calculations and quality scores.  The DF file is a PDF document that contains major assumptions and data sources that are the basis for each unit process.  The NETL Unit Process Library is located on the NETL website (netl.doe.gov) under Research / Energy Analysis / Energy Trends and Issues / Life Cycle Analysis / Unit Process Library.

This dataset was converted directly from the DS with additional supporting information provided by the DF.  Full citations for the DS and DF are given below.

DS File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2010. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data – Unit Process: Mining Truck for Surface Mine, 623,690 kg, Construction. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last Updated: February 2010 (version  01). Retrieved on 06/30/2014 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DS_Stage1_C_Mining_Truck_623690kg_2010-01.xls

DF File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2010. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data – Unit Process: Mining Truck for Surface Mine, 623,690 kg, Construction. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last Updated: February 2010 (version  01). Retrieved on 06/30/2014 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DF_Stage1_C_Mining_Truck_623690kg_2010-01.pdf

category.name: Bit. Coal and Lignite Surface Mining

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This data set is representative of best available public data from 01/01/2003 to 12/31/2003 and is not subject to limited usability within sub-time spans (e.g. summer, winter).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription:
The scope of this unit process encompasses the materials and weights of materials necessary to construct a single 623,690 kg mining truck, to be used for the transportation of coal at a surface mine located in the Powder River Basin region of the United States, during raw material acquisition. This process is used during LC (Life Cycle) Stage #1 to assist in the preparation of subbituminous coal extraction process by transporting the coal within the boundaries of the surface mine. 

Construction of the mining truck is based on manufacturer specifications for a Caterpillar model 797B, 623,690 kg mining truck. The mining truck is used to transport extracted coal to the crushing facility in preparation for transport. All use of the mining truck occurs within the confines of the mine. A visual representation of the boundary of this unit process is available in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section in the Description field).
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: All elementary and technosphere flows are calculated on a functional unit basis. Calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful work are done using lower heating values (LHV) and calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful heat are done using higher heating values (HHV). Unless explicitly stated in the associated reference documents applicable calculations assumed standard atmospheric temperature and pressure (SATP).

processDocumentation.intendedApplication: This is a gate-to-gate manufacturing process and can be used for any type of LCA study.
